reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “random walk” visualization used to motivate the idea that further reflection may increase moral divergence. That point supports pessimism about WAM-convergence, but it is not load-bearing for the overall position: the essay also gives multiple independent reasons (metaethics/realism vs antirealism, motivation, social conformity, post-AGI divergence, threats/lock-in) for doubting widespread accurate motivational convergence. So centrality is modest. The critique has some force insofar as the random-walk framing can implicitly assume a lack of truth-tracking or attractors, and the authors don’t fully justify the model at that moment. However, the essay does later explicitly discuss “attractors” via moral realism/convergence and says reflection is only “at least partially” random, so the critique doesn’t cleanly refute the authors’ broader claim—at most it weakens one illustrative sub-argument/intuition pump. The critique is clear, focused, and has little fluff, but it somewhat overstates by implying the authors give “no argument” relevant to attractors (they do elsewhere), so correctness is good but not perfect.
title: The random walk metaphor assumes moral reflection lacks truth-tracking properties
